{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3240082,"name":"Oliver | 1986","username":"Oliver_W","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oliver_w/{size}/231411_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-13T03:10:42.965Z","cooked":"

For some reason the right two drive motors of our swerve drive are inverted. I tried inverting the drive motors on the two modules, and this fixed the issue. However this caused them to be going against the other 2 modules when turning.

https://github.com/ImpactTang/Cowtown-2023/tree/experimental
(Don‚Äôt mind the other subsystem code, that is still a major work in progress.

maybe this would help:

early on in team 100 swerve work we tried to make the two ‚Äúsides‚Äù of the robot into mirror images of each other, so that the bevel gears would face inwards.

this led to no end of confusion about what the meaning of ‚Äúinverted‚Äù was.

so now we define ‚Äúzero‚Äù to be ‚Äúbevels to the right‚Äù, so every module is identical, nothing is inverted.

Ok, we were turning our gears in so that will probably help a ton. Thank you

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-10-13T04:18:45.366Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442320,"topic_slug":"right-side-of-swerve-drive-inverted","display_username":"Oliver | 1986","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1986 Driver | MoSim Co-Developer"},"post_url":"/t/right-side-of-swerve-drive-inverted/442320/3","custom_user_title":"1986 Driver | MoSim Co-Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3240141,"name":"Alexander Hamilton","username":"GalexY","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galexy/{size}/200203_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-13T07:33:51.860Z","cooked":"

One thing that my team did to fix this issue was calibrating the zero-offset that we have for each absolute encoder. Since we use MAX Swerve it is a bit different than yours, but I noticed that there are not any angular offsets that are applied to each module. In theeeorry (maybe not best practice) the encoders on the right can have an offset of PI or 180 degrees, to ultimately end up flipping them. Don‚Äôt mind that the numbers are not simplified, it helped in the moment and we never really fixed it‚Ä¶ Sorry! (I think we went by each module and one by one added an offset to the module until all four were working properly. I‚Äôm sure the 90 addition was a product of X and Y being flipped when using field-oriented drive/autonomous commands.)

Constants location:

github.com

Patribots4738/ChargedUp2023/blob/main/src/main/java/calc/Constants.java#L64


      
    
          
  1. 
          
  2. public static final SwerveDriveKinematics DRIVE_KINEMATICS = new SwerveDriveKinematics(
    3. 
          
  3.                    // Front Positive,   Left Positive
    4. 
          
  4.     new Translation2d( WHEEL_BASE / 2,  TRACK_WIDTH / 2),  // Front Left
    5. 
          
  5.     new Translation2d( WHEEL_BASE / 2, -TRACK_WIDTH / 2),  // Front Right
    6. 
          
  6.     new Translation2d(-WHEEL_BASE / 2,  TRACK_WIDTH / 2),  // Rear  Left
    7. 
          
  7.     new Translation2d(-WHEEL_BASE / 2, -TRACK_WIDTH / 2)); // Rear  Right
    8. 
          
  8. 
          
  9. // Angular offsets of the modules relative to the chassis in radians
    10. 
          
  10. // add 90 degrees to change the X and Y axis
    11. 
          
  11. public static final double FRONT_LEFT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET = Math.toRadians(180+90);
    12. 
          
  12. public static final double FRONT_RIGHT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET = Math.toRadians(-90+90);
    13. 
          
  13. public static final double BACK_LEFT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET = Math.toRadians(90+90);
    14. 
          
  14. public static final double BACK_RIGHT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET = Math.toRadians(0+90);
    15. 
          
  15. 
          
  16. // Driving motors CAN IDs (EVEN)
    17. 
          
  17. public static final int FRONT_LEFT_DRIVING_CAN_ID = 3;
    18. 
          
  18. public static final int REAR_LEFT_DRIVING_CAN_ID = 5;
    19. 
          
  19. public static final int FRONT_RIGHT_DRIVING_CAN_ID = 1;
    20. 
          
  20. public static final int REAR_RIGHT_DRIVING_CAN_ID = 7;
    21. 
          
  21.

Implementation:

Patribots4738/ChargedUp2023/blob/main/src/main/java/hardware/Swerve.java#L50

  2. private final MAXSwerveModule frontLeft = new MAXSwerveModule(
    3. 
          
  3.     DriveConstants.FRONT_LEFT_DRIVING_CAN_ID,
    4. 
          
  4.     DriveConstants.FRONT_LEFT_TURNING_CAN_ID,
    5. 
          
  5.     DriveConstants.FRONT_LEFT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET);
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
  7. private final MAXSwerveModule frontRight = new MAXSwerveModule(
    8. 
          
  8.     DriveConstants.FRONT_RIGHT_DRIVING_CAN_ID,
    9. 
          
  9.     DriveConstants.FRONT_RIGHT_TURNING_CAN_ID,
    10. 
          
  10.     DriveConstants.FRONT_RIGHT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET);
    11. 
          
  11. 
          
  12. private final MAXSwerveModule rearLeft = new MAXSwerveModule(
    13. 
          
  13.     DriveConstants.REAR_LEFT_DRIVING_CAN_ID,
    14. 
          
  14.     DriveConstants.REAR_LEFT_TURNING_CAN_ID,
    15. 
          
  15.     DriveConstants.BACK_LEFT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET);
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17. private final MAXSwerveModule rearRight = new MAXSwerveModule(
    18. 
          
  18.     DriveConstants.REAR_RIGHT_DRIVING_CAN_ID,
    19. 
          
  19.     DriveConstants.REAR_RIGHT_TURNING_CAN_ID,
    20. 
          
  20.     DriveConstants.BACK_RIGHT_CHASSIS_ANGULAR_OFFSET);
    21.

‚Üí

github.com

Patribots4738/ChargedUp2023/blob/main/src/main/java/hardware/MAXSwerveModule.java#L154


      
    
          
  1. 
          
  2. /**
    3. 
          
  3.  * Sets the desired state for the module.
    4. 
          
  4.  *
    5. 
          
  5.  * @param desiredState Desired state with speed and angle.
    6. 
          
  6.  */
    7. 
          
  7. public void setDesiredState(SwerveModuleState desiredState) {
    8. 
          
  8.     // Apply chassis angular offset to the desired state.
    9. 
          
  9.     SwerveModuleState correctedDesiredState = new SwerveModuleState();
    10. 
          
  10.     correctedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond = desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond;
    11. 
          
  11.     correctedDesiredState.angle = desiredState.angle.plus(Rotation2d.fromRadians(chassisAngularOffset));
    12. 
          
  12. 
          
  13.     // Optimize the reference state to avoid spinning further than 90 degrees.
    14. 
          
  14.     SwerveModuleState optimizedDesiredState = SwerveModuleState.optimize(correctedDesiredState,
    15. 
          
  15.             new Rotation2d(turningEncoder.getPosition()));
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17.     // Command driving and turning SPARKS MAX towards their respective setpoints.
    18. 
          
  18.     drivingPIDController.setReference(optimizedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond, CANSparkMax.ControlType.kVelocity);
    19. 
          
  19.     turningPIDController.setReference(optimizedDesiredState.angle.getRadians(), CANSparkMax.ControlType.kPosition);
    20. 
          
  20. 
          
  21.     this.desiredState = desiredState;
    22.

yes 100%, verifying the absolute encoder value of each module (and adjusting the offset if necessary) is part of the pre-match checklist. these offsets will change if you, say, disassemble the modules for maintenance, depending on what kind of module you‚Äôre using (I think SDS offsets survive disassembly?)
